TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit EndpointAddressMessageFilter extends System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.MessageFilter

Docs.summary: Represents a query that tests whether a message satisfies the requirements of a specified endpoint address.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This filter tests whether a message satisfies a particular endpoint address. An <xref:System.ServiceModel.EndpointAddress> object includes a URI and an optional collection of addressing headers. The addressing and message headers are canonicalized in order to be compared for equality. If a parameter appears more than once in an <xref:System.ServiceModel.EndpointAddress>, the corresponding header must appear in the message at least that many times.
IIS and the underlying file system (NTFS or FAT) are case-insensitive. URI comparisons done by this class are also case-insensitive. So, for example, `http://www.microsoft.com` is evaluated as equal to `http://WWW.microsoft.com`.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
If you have a web service installed on your local machine, there are many equivalent ways to reference it, including the following:
- `http://localhost/foo.svc` - `http://192.168.1.100/foo.svc` - `http://[my-machine-name]/foo.svc` - `http://[my-machine-name].[my-company].com/foo.svc`
If the value of the `includeHostNameInComparison` parameter is `false`, the above URIs all resolve to the same endpoint.

Docs.returns: An object that implements the interface that can contain s with associated .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The method returns an instance of <xref:System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.IMessageFilterTable%601> that is optimized to test for specific message endpoints.
This method is intended to be used by <xref:System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.MessageFilterTable%601>. Use <xref:System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.IMessageFilterTable%601> constructors to create filter table instances.

Docs.value: if the host name is included in the endpoint address comparison; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks
If you have a web service installed on your local machine, there are many equivalent ways to reference it, including the following:
- `http://localhost/foo.svc` - `http://192.168.1.100/foo.svc` - `http://[my-machine-name]/foo.svc` - `http://[my-machine-name].[my-company].com/foo.svc`
The default value of this property is `false`, so the above URIs all resolve to the same endpoint, unless you change this property.

Docs.summary: Tests whether a message or buffered message satisfies the criteria of the endpoint filter.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The difference between the two overloads of the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.EndpointAddressMessageFilter.Match%2A> method is that the one that takes the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageBuffer> parameter is permitted to examine the body of a message when testing for a match, while the one that takes the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Channels.Message> parameter is not.
<xref:System.ServiceModel.Dispatcher.EndpointAddressMessageFilter.Match%2A> does not test the contents of the body of a message, so these two methods are equivalent.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance bool Match(class System.ServiceModel.Channels.Message message) cil managed
Public Overrides Function Match (message As Message) As Boolean

Docs.summary: Tests whether a message satisfies the specified endpoint address.
Docs.returns: if the object satisfies the endpoint address specified in the filter; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The two overloads of this method are equivalent because they both examine only message headers.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance bool Match(class System.ServiceModel.Channels.MessageBuffer messageBuffer) cil managed
Public Overrides Function Match (messageBuffer As MessageBuffer) As Boolean

Docs.summary: Tests whether a buffered message satisfies the specified endpoint address.
Docs.returns: if the object satisfies the endpoint address; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The two overloads of this method are equivalent because they both examine only message headers. The only reason to use this overload is if you already had a `messageBuffer` available and not a message, because this method converts the `messageBuffer` into a message.
